They are seldom wound back or even revised, and the net result has been a severe reduction in our freedoms and liberties. It’s time for a Charter of Rights to protect the things we value.
Over the last 20 years, well over 200 pieces of legislation which curtail fundamental rights and freedoms have been passed through Australian parliaments.
These laws are poorly drafted, rushed and typically for this government, show a complete disregard for people’s basic rights like privacy.
We could flesh all of these issues out if the Parliament was at least given the opportunity to scrutinise this Bill through the committee process, but we have been denied that chance.

This is a very low threshold, and would catch things like minor drug offences and even breaches of the Copyright Act. This means that security agencies could potentially covertly access people’s devices on the basis that they contain unlicensed versions of movies or songs.
To obtain a data disruption warrant, the AFP or ACIC would need to show that it was necessary to frustrate an offence carrying a maximum penalty of three years imprisonment.

As always, Peter Dutton is using the threat of terrorism and the most serious offences imaginable to scare people into accepting this legislation, but in reality the thresholds are set at a much lower level.
This Bill creates three new types of warrants that would allow officers to modify, add, copy or delete information on people’s devices, and in some cases, take over people’s accounts.

Last week, the Government introduced the Surveillance Legislation Amendment (Identify And Disrupt) Bill. It gives security agencies massive new powers to access data on people’s computers and devices, and they are trying to rush it through Parliament.

But to make all that happen, we need to inject some justice and some democracy into our economy.
 
That’s what economic justice means, and the Australian Greens are ready for the fight.

Economic justice means our governments must fund new and better services for our people – health, education, childcare, aged care, housing and public transport to improve everyone’s lives.

Because that’s how we can build the foundations of a fair, clean economy.

Economic justice means a better way. There is more than enough wealth in Australia to pay for a good life for all of us, to restore our environment and help repair our climate.
 
Economic justice means a Green New Deal.
We are in the first recession for a generation and the government’s response is to bring forward tax cuts for the wealthy, and let the big corporates off the hook.

Economic justice means opposing the neoliberal agenda of austerity for the poor and tax cuts for the super wealthy. Let us not mince words - austerity kills people.

The Government had better be ready for a fight on this front.

Economic justice means fighting to make corporations and the very wealthy pay their fair share of tax.

And it means fighting for people who are made to beg and scrape for the pittance they receive as income support, forced to apply for jobs that are simply not there.

Economic justice means an economy that serves people, instead of the other way around.

And economic justice means an economy that respects nature, instead of one which destroys the environment and cooks the planet.

We’ve had a portfolio reshuffle in the Greens, and I’ve been given the new role of Economic Justice spokesperson.

We’ve named this exciting new portfolio to reflect exactly what we want to achieve, and what we think our economy should deliver.

Peter Dutton is trying to put himself above the law. He has been allowed to sit at the head of a huge national security body, and now wields power arbitrarily and without consequence.
And when the case is referred to the police, we get stuck in a Kafkaesque spiral where apparently it's impossible for the minister or his office to have broken the law.
So we have a senior government minister or his office leaking private medical information and other classified material to a favourite journalist to push an agenda.

A few months later, the AFP put out a statement claiming the referral was made in error. Days later, an FOI  revealed details of the case under the heading "unauthorised disclosure where the subject of the referral was found to be authorised... by a government minister".
Home Affairs Secretary Mike Pezzullo then referred the matter to the AFP.
It was an egregious breach of privacy from a government and a news organisation with shocking records of this kind of bullshit.

The very next day, a story appeared in the Courier Mail detailing a refugee's transfer from Nauru, including private medical information, the man's Facebook photos and an estimated cost of the transfer, which matched what Home Affairs told Dutton's office.
That information was duly provided, as well as explicit instructions that it was not for public release.
Last year, as Dutton was railing against the Medevac laws, someone in his office requested information from the Department of Home Affairs about the cost of medical transfers to Taiwan.
